```java
public boolean streamContainsString(InputStream inputStream, String searchString) throws IOException {
    byte[] buffer = new byte[1024];
    int numBytesRead;
    int searchStringLength = searchString.length();
    int bufferLength = 0;
    int bufferStartIndex = 0;
    while ((numBytesRead = inputStream.read(buffer, bufferLength, buffer.length - bufferLength)) > 0) {
        bufferLength += numBytesRead;
        while (bufferLength - bufferStartIndex >= searchStringLength) {
            if (new String(buffer, bufferStartIndex, searchStringLength).equals(searchString)) {
                return true;
            }
            bufferStartIndex++;
        }
        if (bufferLength == buffer.length) {
            System.arraycopy(buffer, bufferStartIndex, buffer, 0, bufferLength - bufferStartIndex);
            bufferStartIndex = 0;
            bufferLength = buffer.length - bufferStartIndex;
        }
    }
    return false;
}
```
<<<explanation>>>: This code reads from the input stream into a buffer. It then checks if the buffer contains the search string. If it does, it returns true. If it doesn't, it shifts the buffer to remove the characters that have been checked and continues. If the buffer is full, it copies the remaining characters to the start of the buffer and continues. This way, the buffer always contains the last characters read from the stream, allowing it to check for the search string across the boundary of the buffer.

Note: This code assumes that the search string is not longer than the buffer size. If it is, you would need to increase the buffer size or find a different approach.
